xldoc.title: Rationality and Romanticism
xldoc.description: A description of two opposing mindsets in modern philosophical thinking, those of the Enlightenment and of some of its principle opponents

section.title: Overview
section.abstract: Two constrasting views of the proper relationship between the logical and emotional elements of the human psyche, which may be thought representative of distinct lines of development of western philosophy are dissected with a view to a synthesis.

subsec.p: Until recently my philosophical thinking outside the domain of more-or-less analytic philosophy (and meta-philosophy) has hung around utopianism or futurism. This was at a time when I did not think of myself as being exclusively engaged in philosophy, and it was this (possibly but not necessarily or exclusively philosophical) interest in how things might or should be which made me style this website as factasia.
Having now come to feel more exclusively interested in (what at least I think of as) philosophical writing, the centrality of the futuristic, utopian factasia theme feels not quite right.

sbcol.subsec:
Here is Russell's very unsympathetic description. In his History of Western Philosphy [], speaking of the first romantics he says that they:
"... greatly admired what they called sensibilité, which means a proneness to emotion, and more particularly to the emotion of sympathy. To be thoroughly satisfactory, the emotion must be direct and violent and quite uninformed by thought."
Romanticism seems most substantially to have been a literary phenomenon, but in philosophy its most prominent figure was Rousseau. His most influencial work was "The Social Contract" which was a political tract proclaiming the romantic ideal of individual liberty but describing a political system which became the prototype for totalitarian regimes far removed from these romantic roots.

subsec.title: Isaiah Berlin
